name: Catatonic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

content.description: Catatonic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition is characterized by catatonic symptoms directly attributable to a general medical condition, rather than a primary psychiatric disorder. It presents with psychomotor disturbances such as stupor, catalepsy, mutism, negativism, posturing, mannerisms, stereotypy, agitation, grimacing, echolalia, or echopraxia.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Clinical picture dominated by three or more of the following: (1) stupor, (2) catalepsy, (3) waxy flexibility, (4) mutism, (5) negativism, (6) posturing, (7) mannerism, (8) stereotypy, (9) agitation not influenced by external stimuli, (10) grimacing, (11) echolalia, (12) echopraxia. B. Evidence from history, physical exam, or labs that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition. C. Not better explained by another mental disorder. D. Not occurring exclusively during delirium. E. Causes clinically significant distress or impairment.
content.prevalence: Uncommon; most often occurs in the setting of neurological or systemic medical conditions such as encephalitis, stroke, metabolic disorders.
content.age_of_onset: Varies based on underlying medical illness.
content.prognosis: Prognosis depends on prompt diagnosis and treatment of both the catatonia and the underlying medical condition; delayed intervention increases risk of complications and mortality.

circuitry: Disruption of cortical and basal ganglia pathways regulating motor function and arousal.
neurochemistry: Alterations in GABA, glutamate, and dopamine transmission.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: No specific genetic risk; onset linked to precipitating medical condition.

history_psychosocial: Recent onset of motor or behavioral changes in the context of a known or suspected medical condition.
Medication history, substance use, exposure to toxins.
medical_assessment: Laboratory evaluation: CBC, CMP, thyroid function, B12/folate, ESR/CRP, infectious workup, creatine kinase, urine toxicology.
Neuroimaging (MRI/CT) to evaluate for structural or vascular causes.
standardized_measures: Bushâ€“Francis Catatonia Rating Scale (BFCRS) for severity and monitoring.
risk_stratification: Urgent inpatient care if signs of autonomic instability, dehydration, malnutrition, or rapid clinical decline.
evaluation.team_and_process: Collaborative care involving psychiatry, neurology, and internal medicine.

severity_levels.mild: Few catatonic signs, minimal medical compromise.
severity_levels.moderate: Multiple catatonic signs with reduced intake and activity, medical monitoring required.
severity_levels.severe: Severe immobility, mutism, or autonomic instability; high complication risk.

psychological: Secondary effects of medical illness on cognition and behavior
environmental: Exposure to neurotoxins or severe systemic illness

impact_on_life.school_work: Complete incapacity to function during episodes.
impact_on_life.social: Loss of ability to communicate and interact.
impact_on_life.medical: High risk of malnutrition, dehydration, thromboembolism, pressure sores.
impact_on_life.emotional: Distress and confusion for patient and caregivers.

medications: Amantadine or memantine in refractory cases (specialist-guided).
neuromodulation: ECT if benzodiazepines fail and medical status allows.
lifestyle_interventions: Aggressive medical support for nutrition, hydration, prevention of immobility complications.
care_coordination: Close multidisciplinary monitoring in inpatient setting.

missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing immobility and mutism solely to delirium or depression without evaluating for catatonia
overdiagnosis_factors: Misinterpreting general psychomotor slowing from medical illness as catatonia

specifiers.with_malignant_features: Severe form with autonomic instability, hyperthermia, altered consciousness, high mortality risk.

warning_signs: Sudden onset of mutism and immobility in a medically ill patient
self_help_strategies: Adherence to medical treatment for underlying condition
Early reporting of unusual motor or speech changes

children_adolescents: Often linked to autoimmune encephalitis or metabolic disorders
adults: Frequently due to CNS lesions or systemic metabolic illness
older_adults: High index of suspicion due to polypharmacy and neurological disease prevalence

real_life_examples: A 60-year-old with autoimmune encephalitis develops mutism, posturing, and negativism, resolving after high-dose lorazepam and immunotherapy.
content.when_to_seek_help: Immediate emergency evaluation if sudden motor arrest, mutism, or bizarre posturing occurs in the setting of medical illness.
